articles.headline: F.A.A. Impasse That Hit 4,000 Ends, for Now
articles.snippet: The agreement signals an end to a standoff over policy issues that had left 4,000 agency employees out of work.
articles.abstract: The agreement signals an end to a standoff over policy issues that had left 4,000 agency employees out of work.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has reached a patchwork agreement with Congressional leaders to end a 13-day partial shutdown of the Federal Aviation Administration, the Senate majority leader,  Harry Reid, said Thursday.

articles.headline: Shell Gets Tentative Approval to Drill in Arctic
articles.snippet: The move is another sign that the Obama administration is easing the clampdown on offshore oil drilling.
articles.abstract: The move is another sign that the Obama administration is easing the clampdown on offshore oil drilling.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Department of the Interior on Thursday granted Royal Dutch Shell conditional approval of its plan to begin drilling exploratory wells in the Arctic Ocean next summer, a strong sign that the Obama administration is easing a regulatory clampdown on offshore oil drilling that it imposed after last year’s deadly accident in the Gulf of Mexico.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Disapproval Rate for Congress at Record 82% After Debt Talks
articles.snippet: In wake of the debt-ceiling debate, most Americans surveyed said creating jobs should now take priority over cutting spending, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.abstract: In wake of the debt-ceiling debate, most Americans surveyed said creating jobs should now take priority over cutting spending, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.lead_paragraph: The debate over raising the debt ceiling, which brought the nation to the brink of default, has sent disapproval of Congress to its highest level on record and left most Americans saying that creating jobs should now take priority over cutting spending, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Megan Thee-Brenan

articles.headline: Mortgage Settlement Challenged
articles.snippet: Bank of New York Mellon is accused of fraud in its role overseeing loan pools at the heart of an accord with Bank of America.
articles.abstract: Bank of New York Mellon is accused of fraud in its role overseeing loan pools at the heart of an accord with Bank of America.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general is moving to block a proposed $8.5 billion settlement struck in June by Bank of New York Mellon and Bank of America over troubled loan pools issued by Countrywide. A lawsuit filed late Thursday accuses Bank of New York of fraud in its role as trustee overseeing the pools for investors.

articles.headline: Learning to Live With Debt
articles.snippet: Excessive debt and the fear of debt have taken a heavy toll on the economies of the United States and Europe.
articles.abstract: Excessive debt and the fear of debt have taken a heavy toll on the economies of the United States and Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Debt can kill. But you can’t live without it.

articles.headline: Guardians of Internet Security Are Targets
articles.snippet: A string of hackers’ attacks on Internet security companies shows the extent of online vulnerabilities, but the breaches may help the firms grow their business.
articles.abstract: A string of hackers’ attacks on Internet security companies shows the extent of online vulnerabilities, but the breaches may help the firms grow their business.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The Web site of ManTech International, a $2.6 billion computer security company that won a major F.B.I. contract, sells its services this way:

articles.headline: Chinese Officials Seized and Sold Babies, Parents Say
articles.snippet: At least 16 babies were seized by family planning officials from 1999 to 2006 in Hunan Province; parents say the babies were used as a source of revenue.
articles.abstract: At least 16 babies were seized by family planning officials from 1999 to 2006 in Hunan Province; parents say the babies were used as a source of revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONGHUI COUNTY, China — Many parents and grandparents in this mountainous region of terraced rice and sweet potato fields have long known to grab their babies and find the nearest hiding place whenever family planning officials show up. Too many infants, they say, have been snatched by officials, never to be seen again.

articles.headline: Time to Say It: Double Dip Recession May Be Happening
articles.snippet: It has been three decades since the United States suffered a recession that followed on the heels of the previous one. But it could be happening again.
articles.abstract: It has been three decades since the United States suffered a recession that followed on the heels of the previous one. But it could be happening again.

articles.headline: Nervous Investors Chase Low-Risk Assets
articles.snippet: Acting on fears about the global economy on a day the stock markets plunged, investors roared into Treasury bonds, cash and other low-risk assets.
articles.abstract: Acting on fears about the global economy on a day the stock markets plunged, investors roared into Treasury bonds, cash and other low-risk assets.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a frantic flight to safety.

articles.headline: Volatile Wall Street Ends the Day Mixed
articles.snippet: Markets gyrated amid mixed views of the jobs report and fears that the United States and Europe were not doing enough to revive their economies.
articles.abstract: Markets gyrated amid mixed views of the jobs report and fears that the United States and Europe were not doing enough to revive their economies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like a battered boxer, stocks were knocked down and kept dragging themselves up through trading Friday, closing flat in the end, but capping the worst weekly decline since November 2008.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Christine Hauser

articles.headline: U.S. Posts Stronger Job Growth in July
articles.snippet: The U.S. added 117,000 jobs last month, the strongest figure since April, but it may still not be high enough to relieve fears of a renewed recession.
articles.abstract: The U.S. added 117,000 jobs last month, the strongest figure since April, but it may still not be high enough to relieve fears of a renewed recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States economy continues on a wobbly course, but there was a momentary sigh of relief on Friday as the government reported that employers added 117,000 jobs last month, slightly more than expected.
